summary: The Project Manager reviewed the decisions from the previous meeting. The Marketing Expert made a presentation on trend watching, including trends in user requirements and trends in fashion. The Industrial Designer presented all the components of the device and announced that several of the features already discussed would not be available. He suggested substituting a kinetic battery for the rechargeable batteries and using a combination of rubber and plastic for the materials. The User Interface Designer presented his main interface design, which included buttons for the most frequently used features and a graphic user interface on the LCD screen for other functions, to keep frequently used features easy to use. He announced that speech recognition was still an option to consider, depending on price. The Project Manager then began a discussion to decide what was going into the final design. It was decided that a kinetic battery would be used in place of a rechargeable battery, that the remote will feature an LCD screen and rubber casing and rubber buttons, and that interchangeable rubber covers in fruit colors will be available. Speech recognition may be included if it is not too costly.
decisions: It was decided that the remote would feature an LCD screen, rubber buttons, colorful rubber changeable skins, a kinetic battery, and possibly speech recognition if it is still within the budget to include it.
problems: Several of the features that the group had wanted to integrate into the design were either too costly or unavailable due to new limitations from the factory. The group had to change many of the original design elements to an alternative.

Overall, the meeting was very = interactive with=20 all members expressing their opinion in a constructive and democratic=20 way.

ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcComponents_design.ppt ------------ Components Design Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer Method The press of the button should activate the TV Should be able to find easily Looked into AVAILABILITY of materials Findings Main chip used is a “TA11835”, these are standard and used in most remote controls. Battery options: Standard AA,AAA Dynamo charging Solar Charging Kinetic Charging Findings Most remotes use a silicon board with rubberised buttons When the button is pressed it sends a unique code to the chip This code is processed then output by the chip and sent via the IR LED to the TV. Personal Preferences To conserve battery life the remote should be in a ‘standby’ mode while not being used. Case Material? Plastic, Rubber, Wood, Titanium Interface Designs? Rubber buttons, LCD, Bare?? ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcfinalpresentation.ppt ------------ Look and Feel Presented by: William Cooke & Pawan Negi, Industrial & Interface Designer Exterior Plastic body: Standard colour: White? Blue? Rubber outer casing (changeable facials) Wide choice of colours, patterns Clamshell design Interior Batteries: Kinetic Voice Recognition: “Where is the remote?” “I’m Here!!” Standard transmission with TV, using standard chips, PCB etc. Interface Top Screen: B&W LCD Touch screen Bottom Screen: Rubberised Standard Buttons inc. Volume, Power etc. Also containing the new logo! And that’s how we’ve put the fashion back into electronics! ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant2hBcWorking_design.ppt ------------ Working Design Presented by: William Cooke, Industrial Designer Extraordinaire Method What are we trying to design? -A device which sends a signal to a TV to change its state, (e.g. power button changes on/off and vice versa) Look at what other people have designed and take inspiration Make sure that the new design is original Findings Most remote controls use infrared to send signals to a TV. Most are powered by some form of battery. Small easy to carry round Components Internal: Power Source – Batteries Chips – To decode the input to IR Signal Sender – IR Bulb, Wireless range up to 5m External: Plastic based, UI Design Infrared bulb Bulb Switch Energy source Wire Chip Subcomponent UI Interface TV Receiver IR-Data Personal Preferences Available to a wide audience, cost low. Should be different enough to get a good consumer base. Small, easy to lose? ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant3hBcInterface_concept..1.ppt ------------ Interface Concept Presented by: Pawan Negi -User Interface Designer Method Input from other departments – Marketing and Industrial Design Competitors GUI or Pointing device Findings To many cluttered buttons. Repetition of certain patterns. E.g: The volume and channel control buttons in centre Confusing and inconsistent Voice recognition Personal Preferences Trendy - fruit colour Certain standard buttons Voice recognition ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant3hBcTechnical_functions..1.ppt ------------ Technical Functions Design Presented by: Pawan Negi, User Interface Designer Method Purpose of Remote Control: To simplify the interaction with TV Main Feature – User friendly by being easy-to-use, trendy and engineering marvel. Concept – A Flip top model. Main function on the top and complex function inside with browsing facility. Added features such as shock proof body, trendy design. Findings Most people prefer user friendly rather than complex remote controls Economies of scale -Due to high volume, we could produce this design at a cheaper cost. Personal Preferences Flip top design Trendy colours Soft exterior plastic body and soft buttons Thanks you for your attention. Any comments please. ES2004docs.ES2004scen.participant4hBcEvaluation.ppt ------------ Evaluation criteria Presented by: Dale Anderson Marketing Consultant Method Collection of criteria is based on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and the marketing strategy of the Real Reaction © electronics company. Findings CRITERIA Fancy look-and-feel Technological innovation Easy to use Incorporates current fashion trends Design minimises RSI Easy to locate Evaluation Criteria rating with seven-point scale 1 = TRUE 7 = FALSE To be continued on whiteboard!
